text_description: Apr: The first literary works in English of the pensionado are published in the Filipino Students’ Magazine.
Wallace Stegner visits the Philippines.
Sea Serpent, the first book of poems by Alfred Yuson, is published.

media_caption: Francisco Arcellana
text_description: Francisco Arcellana is declared National Artist.
Oral and indigenous literature of the peoples of the Philippines are created and passed on. This includes riddles, proverbs, tales, epics, and songs of different types.
Indigenous ways of writing flourish.
The newspaper The Philippines Herald is founded.

media_caption: Book cover of Longitude by Carlos Cortes
text_description: The first contact between Spain and what would be the Philippines will inspire literary works such as Longitud by Carlos Cortes and the young adult novel Enrique El Negro by Carla Pacis. (Photo from UP Press)
Pedro Bucaneg transcribes Biag ti Lam-ang, the Ilocano epic.

article_title: Lit 1605 May Bagyo Ma't May Rilim
text_description: “May Bagyo Ma’t Rilim,” the earliest published poem written by a native, is included in Memoria de la Vida Cristiana en Lengua Tagala, evincing the Christianization of the native mind.

media_caption: Our Lady of La Naval de Manila, Santo Domingo Church, Quezon City, with aureola, corona, rostrillo, and frontal of precious metals
media_credit: Photo courtesy of Santo Domingo Church Library
text_description: Nick Joaquin will commemorate the historic event in his essay “La Naval de Manila” and in the poem "The Ballad of the Five Battles."

article_title: Lit 1852 El Libro de la Vida
text_description: Aniceto de la Merced writes the third Filipino pasyon, El Libro de la Vida.
Cebuano writer Sulpicio Osorio publishes an anticlerical novel, Mga Bungsod nga Guipangguba.

media_caption: Consejo de los Dioses was a play written in Spanish by José Rizal, first published in 1880 in Manila. 1918. Jose Rizal, Adaptation by Lope Blas Hucapte
text_description: Liceo Artistico-Literario, a short-lived literary society, sponsors a literary contest. Rizal’s “A la Juventud Filipina” and “El Consejo de los Dioses” receive prizes in 1879 and 1880, respectively.

“Hibik nang Filipinas sa Inang España” by Hermenegildo Flores and “Sagot nang España sa Hibik nang Filipinas” by Marcelo H. del Pilar will appear together. The poems show the growing discontent among Filipinos with Spanish rule.
Jul 15: Rizal’s essay “Sobre la Indolencia de los Filipinos” is published in La Solidaridad.

article_title: Lit 1891.1 Filipinas dentro de Cien Años
text_description: Sep 30: Jose Rizal’s essay “Filipinas dentro de Cien Años” appears in La Solidaridad.
Katipunan supremo Andres Bonifacio publishes "Pag-ibig sa Tinubuang Lupa" and "Ang Dapat Mabatid ng mga Tagalog" in Kalayaan.
Liwanag at Dilim, a collection of aphoristic, lyrical essays by Emilio Jacinto on notions of liberty and equality, is published in Kalayaan.
Dec 29: Jose Rizal writes his last poem "Mi Ultimo Adios."

media_caption: September 18, 1899 issue of the La Independencia
text_description: “Filipinas” by Jose Palma, which provided the lyrics for the national anthem “Himno Nacional Filipinas,” and “Al Heroe Nacional” by Cecilio Apostol are published in La Independencia, to commemorate the death of Jose Rizal. Other nationalistic pieces by Antonio Luna, Manuel Guerrero, and others appear in the newspaper.
Ang Cababalaghan ni P. Bravo by Gabriel Beato Francisco is serialized, the first Tagalog novel.
Iloilo historian Pedro Monteclaro’s Maragtas, which purports to be a record of events in 13th-century Panay, is published. It inspires many, short stories, poems, and essays.

media_caption: Norberto Romualdez
text_description: Sanghiran san Binisaya, whose members include Jaime de Veyra, Iluminado Lucente, and Eduardo Makabenta, is founded by Norberto Romualdez (in photo), heralding the rise in vernacular publications in Leyte and Samar.
“Elias” by Rosauro Almario, generally believed to be the first Tagalog short story, is published in Mithi.

Mar 16: The first in a series of articles on historical events with social or patriotic interest, "Efemerides Filipinas," is serialized in El Ideal, ostensibly to help in the formation of a Filipino consciousness.

The Sunday literary supplement (begun in 1929) of Makinaugalingon will carry the writings of Miguela Montelibano and the “trinidad poetica Ilonga”: Flavio Zaragoza Cano, Delfin Gumban, and Serapion Torre.
Deogracias Rosario publishes “Kung Magmahal ang Makata,” considered by some as the first “munting kasaysayan” or short story in Buntot Pague.
Fundacion Zobel hands out the first Premio Zobel to Guillermo Gomez Windham for La Carrera de Candida, through whose protagonist’s life he depicts the “moral harm” caused by Americanization.
Zoilo Galang’s Kapampangan novel Ing Capalaran, which is distinguished for its use of Spanish and English words and sayings, Tagalog idioms, and humor, is published.
Filipino Poetry, the first anthology of Filipino poems in English, edited by Luis Dato, is published.
The weekly magazine supplement of The Tribune publishes short stories by Filipino writers and will later sponsor a short story contest in 1927.

media_caption: Photo of Paz Marquez-Benitez from the book cover of Paz Marquez Benitez: One woman's life, letters, and writings by Virginia Benitez Licuanan
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press
text_description: “Dead Stars” by Paz Marquez-Benitez, considered the first modern Philippine short story in English, appears in The Philippines Herald.

media_caption: Book cover of Paz Latorena's Desire and Other Stories
media_credit: Photo from University of Santo Tomas Publishing House
text_description: “The Small Key” by Paz Latorena appears in The Philippines Herald. This and other stories of hers that explore the female psyche, like “Desire” and “Sunset” will be collected in Desire and Other Stories in 2000. (Photo from University of Santo Tomas Publishing House)

article_title: Lit 1927.2 Philippine Prose and Poetry first edition
text_description: The first edition of Philippine Prose and Poetry, the first high school textbook to use only Filipino writings, is published.

media_caption: Book Cover of Harvest and Other Stories
media_credit: Photo from De La Salle University Press
text_description: The Philippines Herald publishes Loreto Paras-Sulit's short story “Harvest,” known for its classic opening line: "He first saw her in his brother's eyes." Paras-Sulit's stories will be collected in Harvest and Other Stories in 2001. (Photo from De La Salle University Press)
Deogracias Rosario’s “Ako’y Mayroong Isang Ibon,” regarded as the first “plotless” Tagalog short story, is published. His stories will be collected in Deogracias A. Rosario 1894-1936 in 1995.
An Parabareta, a weekly Bikol newspaper carrying essays, poems, and stories, begins publication.
The magazine Silew is founded. Until 1943, Silew becomes the main publication venue of Pangasinan literature. Among its contributors will be Maria Magsano. It is followed by Sandi’y Silew in 1943.

Rebellious group of young Tagalog writers led by Clodualdo del Mundo Sr and Alejandro G. Abadilla founds Kapisanang Panitikan, or Panitikan, seeking to introduce modernism in Tagalog poetry. They start publication of a literary magazine called Panitikan.
“Vaya con Virgo” by Wilfrido D. Nolledo wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in English.
With its celebration of the individual and use of free verse, the poem "Ako ang Daigdig" by Alejandro Abadilla breaks new ground in Tagalog poetry.

media_caption: Jesus Balmori
text_description: The Commonwealth Literary Awards, the first state-sponsored literary contest, are given. Apart from Manuel Arguilla’s story collection and Salvador P. Lopez’s essay collection, other winners include “Like the Molave” by R. Zulueta da Costa, and “Mi Casa de Nipa” by Jesus Balmori (in photo). Both will be published in 1941.

media_caption: Hemingway posing for a dust jacket photo by Lloyd Arnold for the first edition of "For Whom the Bell Tolls":, at the Sun Valley Lodge, Idaho, late 1939
text_description: Ernest Hemingway visits the Philippines.
The magazines Pillars and Philippine Review are founded, affording writers in English an outlet for their creations.

Emmanuel Torres’s Shapes of Silence, which includes “Another Invitation to the Pope to Visit Tondo,” is published. It reflects the shift to more socially conscious and even politically critical writing among many Filipino writers during the martial law period.

media_caption: Photo of Ramon Muzones
text_description: Staffers of Ilonggo weekly magazine Kasanag form Sumakwelan, seeking to unify all Ilonggo writers and to enrich the Ilonggo language, with Ramon Munzones (in photo) as its first president.
Ang Maikling Kuwentong Tagalog 1886-1948, edited by Teodoro A. Agoncillo, is published, containing some of the best writing done in Tagalog during the first half of the 20th century.

The first Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature is held. It is limited to the short story in English and in Tagalog. The winners are “Clay” by Juan Gatbonton , “The Flowers of May” by Francisco Arcellana, and “The Black Monkey” by Edith Tiempo.
The Pangasinan novel Samban Agnabenegan by Maria Magsano, which follows a marriage wrecked by infidelity, is published.
The first compilation of Tagalog essays, Mga Piling Sanaysay, edited by Alejandro G. Abadilla, is published.

Darna appears in Pilipino Komiks. It is one of many comic book creations of Mars Ravelo, which include Dyesebel, Captain Barbell, and Lastikman. All will be adapted into successful movies and television shows.

Six Filipino Poets, edited by Leonard Casper, is published, evincing the ascendancy of formalism in Philippine poetry in English. Represented are Amador T. Daguio, Dominador I. Ilio, Oscar de Zuniga, Carlos A. Angeles, Edith L. Tiempo, and Ricaredo Demetillo.
Gregorio Sumcad’s social realist novel Sakada, noted for its accurate depiction of a migrant sugar worker’s life, begins serialization in Hiligaynon.
May 21: Akademyang Bikol, an organization intended to develop, standardize, and promote the Bikol language, is founded in Naga City.
Bannawag begins the serialization of Constante Casabar’s Ilocano novel Dagiti Mariing Iti Parbangon, a love story set in crime-ridden 1950s Ilocos and a social commentary on Ilocano politics.

media_caption: Author William Faulkner in 1954. 11 December 1954
media_credit: Photo from Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Van Vechten Collection
text_description: William Faulkner visits the Philippines.
Aug 25: Lubas sa Dagang Bisaya (LUDABI), the largest organization of writers in Cebuano, is established in Cebu City.

Liwayway starts the column “Bagong Dugo,” edited by Liwayway Arceo (in photo), featuring short stories by new writers, advancing the development of modern Tagalog fiction. The column will last until Jan 1963.
Of Cocks and Kites, a collection of humorous stories by Alejandro Roces, is published.

article_title: Lit 1961.1 Bamboo and the Greenwood Tree
text_description: Bamboo and the Greenwood Tree: Essays on Filipino Literature in English by Miguel A. Bernad, one of the first collections of criticism on Philippine literature in English, is published.
A number of Francisco Arcellana’s stories, including “The Mats” and “Flowers of May,” are collected in Selected Stories.
The Pretenders, the first in five-novel Rosales Saga by F. Sionil Jose, chronicling the life of the Samson clan through upheavals in Philippine history, is published.
A Stun of Jewels by Carlos Angeles, the first collection to receive the Palanca award in poetry, is published.

Oct: The first Bagay poems, characterized by colloquial language and concrete imagery—qualities which represent a break from the Balagtas tradition—appear in the Ateneo de Manila campus journal Heights.

media_caption: Cover of The Filipinos in the Philippines and Other Essays by Renato Constantino
text_description: The Filipinos in the Philippines and Other Essays by nationalist historian Renato Constantino is published. It includes “The Miseducation of the Filipino,” which blames the teaching of English for the mental colonization by the United States of the Filipino.
Dilim sa Umaga, a novel by Efren Abueg, is published.
Twenty Cebuano writers, including Ernesto Lariosa, Temistokles Adlawan, Junne Canizares, Ricardo Patalinjug, and Rene Amper, found Bathalad, a major association of writers in Cebuano.

article_title: Lit 1969.3 Kapatid ko ang Aking Ina
text_description: Kapatid Ko ang Aking Ina by Elena Patron is serialized. With this her first novel, she becomes one of the first women to break into the male-dominated world of the komiks. Gilda Olvidado and Nerissa Cabral will follow in her footsteps.
The Ilonggo short story anthology Bahandi I: 46 ka Pili nga mga Sugilanon sa Ilonggo is published, the stories therein mostly taken from Hiligaynon between 1960 and 1970.

“Maria, ang Iyong Anak” by Wilfredo Virtusio, about a mother and her activist son during the height of student activism in the late 1960s and early 1970s, is published. Virtusio’s collected stories Bilanggo at Iba pang Akda will be published in 1992.

media_caption: Book cover of Wilfrido Nolledo's But for the Lovers. 1994 paperback edition published by Dalkey Archive Press
text_description: Wilfrido Nolledo publishes But for the Lovers, a tour de force of a novel set during World War II.

Mar 23: Panulat para sa Kaunlaran ng Sambayanan (PAKSA), which champions national democratic literature for the masses, is officially organized at the Philippine College of Commerce (now Polytechnic University of the Philippines).

article_title: Lit 1971.2 Radical Tradition in Philippine Literature
text_description: The Radical Tradition in Philippine Literature by Epifanio San Juan Jr, which engages such figures as Amado V. Hernandez, Carlos Bulosan, Lope K. Santos, and Jose Ma. Sison from a Marxist perspective, is published.
The Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas (UMPIL) holds its first meeting at the Social Security System Building in Quezon City, with Adrian Cristobal as the organization’s first chairperson.

media_caption: Book cover of Philippine Short Stories 1925-1940 edited by Leopoldo Yabes
text_description: The first of Leopoldo Yabes’s landmark three-volume anthology Philippine Short Stories, covering the 1920s to the early 1950s, is published. The next two volumes will be published in 1981. Between 2009 and 2014, Gemino Abad will extend the scope of Yabes’s anthologies to the 21st century. Photo: Book cover of 2008 edition (UP Press)

media_caption: Book cover of Ulahingan: An Epic of the Southern Philippines by Elena C. Maquiso, Series 1
text_description: Ulahingan: An Epic of the Southern Philippines by Elena C. Maquiso is published.

media_caption: Book cover of Pasyon and Revolution by Reynaldo Ileto
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press
text_description: Pasyon and Revolution by Reynaldo Ileto, an influential study on the link between the pasyon and the formation of a popular revolutionary consciousness and parallel movements like the Katipunan, is published. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press)

media_caption: Logo of The Manila Critics' Circle
text_description: The Manila Critics’ Circle, responsible for the annual National Book Awards, is founded, giving out the first awards in 1982.
The Philippine Literary Arts Council (PLAC) is established.

media_caption: Book cover of Walong Dekada ng Makabagong Tulang Pilipino, edited by Virgilio Almario
article_title: Lit 1981.2 Walong Dekada ng Makabagong Tulang Pilipino
text_description: Walong Dekada ng Makabagong Tulang Pilipino, edited by Virgilio Almario, is published, an anthology of poems between 1900 and 1980 by 45 poets. (Photo from Philippine Educators Co., Inc)

media_caption: Book cover of Utos ng Hari at Iba pang Kuwento by Jun Cruz Reyes.
text_description: Jun Cruz Reyes publishes his first short story collection, Utos ng Hari at Iba pang Kuwento. The title story, with its colloquialisms and irreverence, has come to epitomize youthful "anti-establishment." (Photo from New Day Publishers)
Philippine Folk Literature, the first in a pioneering series of anthologies of folk literature edited by Damiana Eugenio, is published.

media_caption: Photo of Carlos P. Romulo
media_credit: Photo from Presidential Museum and Library PH
text_description: Carlos P. Romulo is declared National Artist.

media_caption: Book cover of Resil Mojares’s Origins and Rise of the Filipino Novel
article_title: Lit 1983.1 Origins and Rise of the Filipino Novel
text_description: Resil Mojares’s Origins and Rise of the Filipino Novel is published. (Photo from University of the Philippines Press)

media_caption: Book cover of The Writer and His Milieu
article_title: Lit 1984.1 The Writer and His Milieu
text_description: The Writer and His Milieu, an oral history of Filipino writers in English by Edilberto N. Alegre and Doreen G. Fernandez, is published. The second volume, Writers and Their Milieu, will be published in 1987. Photo: Book cover of 2013 reprint (Anvil Publishing, Inc)

media_caption: Book cover of Bata, Bata, Paano Ka Ginawa by Lualhati Bautista
article_title: Lit 1984.3 Bata, Bata, Paano ka Ginawa
text_description: “Bata, Bata, Paano Ka Ginawa” by Lualhati Bautista and “Bata, Sinaksak, Isinilid sa Baul” by Tony Perez share the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino. Written in Taglish, Bautista’s novel about a liberated woman’s predicaments in conventional society, will be published in 1988.

media_caption: PANULAT founding (CCP Coordinating Center for Literature)
text_description: Pambansang Unyon ng mga Manunulat, or Panulat, which advocates the welfare of writers and undertakes grassroots-writing workshops, is founded.
On the occasion of the bicentenary of Francisco Balagtas, the CCP publishes Himalay Balagtas, a collection of historical and critical studies on the poet. It will publish Himalay Rizal in 1991.
Carlo Vergara’s graphic novel Ang Kagilagilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Zsazsa Zaturnnah, helps revive the local komiks industry. (Photo from Visual Print Enterprises Inc)

media_caption: Book cover of Vicente Rafael's Contracting Colonialism
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press
text_description: Vicente Rafael publishes Contracting Colonialism, notable for its pioneering reading of early Tagalog society’s experience of Christian conversion. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press)

media_caption: Book cover of Man of Earth
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press
text_description: Man of Earth, the first volume, coedited by Edna Zapanta Manlapaz, in Gemino Abad’s comprehensive anthology of Philippine poetry in English is published where he expounds on “writing from English.” The other two volumes are A Native Clearing, 1993, and A Habit of Shores, 1999. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press)

media_caption: Book cover of Teo Antonio's Taga sa Bato.
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press
text_description: Teo Antonio publishes Taga sa Bato, a showcase of his wide repertoire of styles and material. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press)

media_caption: Book cover of Ruth Elynia S. Mabanglo's Kung Di Man.
text_description: Ruth Elynia S. Mabanglo publishes Kung Di Man, a collection of love poems that foreground female desire.
“Bulaklak ng Maynila” by Domingo G. Landicho and “Moog” by Buenaventura S. Medina Jr share the Palanca Grand Prize for the novel in Filipino.
Bathalad-Mindanao, an offshoot of Bathalad that seeks to distinguish their “Bisaya” language from Cebu-based Cebuano, is formed in Cagayan de Oro.
Ali*Bang+Bang Atbp. Kwento by Rolando Tolentino and Pitada by Eli Guieb are published as one volume, marking the emergence of a new generation of technically innovative Tagalog fictionists.

media_caption: Book cover of the first of the Twisted books by Jessica Zafra
text_description: The first of the Twisted books by Jessica Zafra, compilations of her columns, is printed, representing the sensibility of a generation. (Photo from Anvil Publishing, Inc)
The anthology Tinigpigan, edited by Victor Sugbo, is published and brings the works of Waray poets past and present Trinchera, Lucente, Makabenta, and de Veyra in book form.

media_caption: Book cover of Prosang Itim by Mike Bigornia
text_description: Prosang Itim by Mike Bigornia, continuing the long local tradition of prose poetry, is published and becomes a bestseller. (Photo from Anvil Publishing, Inc)

media_caption: Book cover of Recuerdo by Cristina Pantoja-Hidalgo
text_description: “Recuerdo,” an epistolary novel by Cristina Pantoja-Hidalgo, wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in English. It is published in the same year. (Photo from University of the Philippines Press)
“Malaybay” by Edmund Coronel wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino.

media_caption: Book cover of Pagbasa ng Panitikan at Kulturang Popular by Soledad Reyes
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press
article_title: Lit 1997 Pagbasa ng Panitikan at Kulturang Popular
text_description: Pagbasa ng Panitikan at Kulturang Popular by Soledad Reyes, which collects her pioneering studies in Philippine popular culture, is published.

media_caption: Photo of Cristina Pantoja Hidalgo
text_description: Coming Home, which epitomizes Cristina Pantoja Hidalgo’s creative nonfiction, is published. (Photo from philstar.com)

media_caption: National Artist Rolando S. Tinio
media_credit: Photo from CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer
text_description: Rolando S. Tinio is declared National Artist in Literature and Theater.

media_caption: Toto O. By Charmaine Lasar
text_description: “Toto O.” by Charmaine Lasar wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino and will be published in 2016. (Photo from PageJump Media)

article_title: Lit 1999 Ang Tulisan at Iba pang Talinghaga
text_description: Ang Tulisan at Iba pang Talinghaga by Florentino Collantes, a comprehensive collection of the author’s work, is published.

media_caption: Book cover of Ang Kaulayaw ng Agila by Lilia Quindoza Santiago
media_credit: Photo from University of the Philippines Press
text_description: “Ang Kaulayaw ng Agila” by Lilia Quindoza Santiago wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino. It will be published in 2002. (Photo from University of the Philippines Press)

media_caption: Cover of A B N K K B S N P L A ko?! by Bob Ong
text_description: A B N K K B S N P L A ko?!, a humorous take on school mores and social institutions by enigmatic author Bob Ong, breaks local publishing records. (Photo from Visprint)

media_caption: Book cover of Knife's Edge by Edel Garcellano
media_credit: Photo from University of the Philippines Press
text_description: Knife’s Edge, which collects Edel Garcellano’s Marxist critiques on local literary production and practices, is published. (Photo from University of the Philippines Press)

media_caption: Tanghalang Pilipino’s Zsazsa Zaturnnah: Ze Muzikal, 2011, a stage adaptation of Carlo Vergara’s graphic novel Ang Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Zsazsa Zaturnnah
text_description: High Chair, a group of poets and a small press known for what some describe as “high modernist” poetics, is formed.

article_title: Lit 2002.3 Kung Paano ko Inayos ang Buhok ko
text_description: “Kung Paano Ko Inayos ang Buhok Ko Matapos ang Mahaba-haba Ring Paglalakbay” by Norman Wilwayco wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino.

media_caption: Book cover of Jolography by Paolo Manalo
media_credit: Photo from University of the Philippines Press
text_description: Paolo Manalo’s poetry collection Jolography, with its novel use of Taglish, is published. (Photo from University of the Philippines Press)

media_caption: Book cover of Feast and Famine by Rosario Cruz Lucero
media_credit: Photo from University of the Philippines Press
text_description: Rosario Cruz Lucero’s Feast and Famine, a collection of stories that deftly engage Negrense history and folklore, is published. (Photo from University of the Philippines Press)

media_caption: Book cover of Romulo Baquiran's Onyx
media_credit: Photo from University of the Philippines Press
text_description: Romulo Baquiran’s Onyx, a showcase of both modernist free verse and traditional forms, is published. (Photo from University of the Philippines Press)
Don Pagusara’s Qontrapuntal, notable for poems that critique local literary practices and for erotic poems, is published.

article_title: Lit 2003.4 Ang Misteryo ng Inuslang Kasingkasing
text_description: Gumer Rafanan’s novel Ang Misteryo sa Inuslang Kasingkasing begins to be serialized in Bisaya.
Textanaga and Dalitext are published, attesting to the influence of new media in the production and circulation of literature.

media_caption: Book cover of Dark Hours by Conchitina R. Cruz
media_credit: Photo from University of the Philippines Press
text_description: Dark Hours by Conchitina Cruz, with poems that make use of devices like marginalia and footnotes, is published.(Photo from University of the Philippines Press)

media_caption: Book cover of Davao, Reconstructing History from Text and Memory by Macario D. Tiu
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Davao University Research and Publication Office
article_title: Lit 2005.1 Davao, Reconstructing History from Text and Memory
text_description: Davao, Reconstructing History from Text and Memory, Macario D. Tiu’s account of Davao history, indigenous groups, myths, and legends, is published. (Photo from Ateneo de Davao University Research and Publication Office)

media_caption: Book cover of “Unang Ulan ng Mayo” by Ellen Sicat
text_description: “Unang Ulan ng Mayo” by Ellen Sicat wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino. It will be published in 2016. (Photo from Anvil Publishing, Inc)
The UBOD New Authors series of the NCCA is launched, allowing new voices using the vernaculars to be heard.

media_caption: Book cover of Mostly in Monsoon Weather by Marne Kilates
media_credit: Photo from University of the Philippines Press
text_description: Marne Kilates’s Mostly in Monsoon Weather and Other Poems is published. (Photo from University of the Philippines Press)

media_caption: Book cover of Trese: Murder on Balete Drive
text_description: The first in Budgette Tan’s Trese series of graphic novels, which situates local mythological creatures in the contemporary city, is published.

article_title: Lit 2008.1 Ang Gakit ni Noebong ug Ubang mga Sugilanon
text_description: Saturnino Apoyon’s Ang Gakit ni Noebong ug Ubang mga Sugilanon, a sympathetic chronicle of the lives of indigenous Bagobo and Tiruray tribes, the Badjao sea gypsies, and barrio folk and city folk, is published.

article_title: Lit 2008.2 Ang Kabaho, Unya ang Kahumot sa Pulbos
text_description: Temistokles Adlawan’s Ang Kabaho, Unya ang Kahumot sa Pulbos, notable for capturing the polyphonic registers of Cebuano, serialized in Bisaya.

media_caption: Book cover of Inintokan by Victor Sugbo
media_credit: Photo from University of the Philippines Press
text_description: Victor Sugbo’s Inintokan, with poems in Waray that chronicle the author’s journey through his native homeland, is published. (Photo from University of the Philippines Press)

article_title: Lit 2008.4 An Maupay ha mga Waray ug iba pa nga mga Siday
text_description: Voltaire Oyzon’s An Maupay ha mga Waray ug Iba pa nga mga Siday, which marks a new contemporary direction for the Waray poetic form siday, is published.

media_caption: Book cover of “Gerilya” by Norman Wilwayco
text_description: “Gerilya” by Norman Wilwayco is published after winning the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino. (Photo from Bookay Ukay Libruhan)

media_caption: Book cover of Batbat hi Udan by Telesforo S. Sungkit Jr
text_description: Batbat hi Udan by Telesforo S. Sungkit Jr, a novel that uses the devices of the epic, is published. (Photo from Central Book Supply Inc)

media_caption: Book cover of Adonis Durado’s Minugbo Alang sa Mugbo og Kalipay
article_title: Lit 2009.1 Minugbo Alang sa Mugbo og Kalipay
text_description: Adonis Durado’s Minugbo Alang sa Mugbo og Kalipay, with poems written in indigenous Cebuano forms like garay and tigmo but using modern material, is published. (Photo from Aistemus and Bathalad, Inc)

media_caption: Book cover of Albay Viejo by Raffi Banzuela
text_description: Albay Viejo by Raffi Banzuela (b. 1951), a collection of essays, historical narratives, and short stories on Albay, is published. (Photo from planet.naga.ph)
Francisco Macansantos’s Balsa: Poemas Chabacanos is published.

media_caption: Book cover of The Mango Bride by Marivi Soliven
article_title: Lit 2011.1 In the Service of Secrets
text_description: “In the Service of Secrets” by Marivi Soliven wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in English. It will be retitled The Mango Bride and published in 2013. (Photo from NAL Accent/Penguin Group)

media_caption: Book cover of “Ang Banal na Aklat ng Mga Kumag” by Allan Derain
article_title: Lit 2011.2 Ang Banal na Aklat ng mga Kumag
text_description: “Ang Banal na Aklat ng Mga Kumag” by Allan Derain wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino. It will be published in 2013. (Photo from Cacho Publishing House)

media_caption: Book cover of Merlie Alunan’s Pagdakop sa Bulalakaw ug Uban pang Mga Balak
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press
article_title: Lit 2012 Pagdakop sa Bulalakaw ug Uban pang Mga Balak
text_description: Merlie Alunan’s Pagdakop sa Bulalakaw ug Uban pang Mga Balak, the author’s first book of Cebuano poetry and which includes equally masterful English translations, is published. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press)

media_caption: Book cover of Diary ng Panget
text_description: Diary ng Panget is published as a book after being serialized on the online platform Wattpad in 2011, epitomizing both a new form called pop fiction and a trend in literary reproduction, from digital to print media rather than vice versa. It will be adapted into a movie in 2014. (Photo from PSICOM Publishing Inc.)

media_caption: Book cover of “Tatlong Gabi, Tatlong Araw” by Eros Atalia
text_description: “Tatlong Gabi, Tatlong Araw” by Eros Atalia wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino and is published. (Photo from Visprint, Inc)

media_caption: Book cover of Book 1 of Sugidanon(Epics) of Panay by Alice Magos
media_credit: Photo from University of the Philippines Press
text_description: The first volume of Sugidanon (Epics) of Panay, by Alice Magos, is published. (Photo from University of the Philippines Press)

media_caption: Book cover of “All My Lonely Islands” by Victorette Joy Z. Campilan.
text_description: “All My Lonely Islands” by Victorette Joy Z. Campilan wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in English and will be published in 2017.
